Human aging is when our body changes over time. Cells in our body get old and don't work as well. This happens because our cells have a limit on how many times they can divide. Also, our DNA, which holds our body's instructions, can get damaged. These changes make us more likely to get sick and weak. We call this process aging. It happens to everyone, but at different speeds.

Here is the final paragraph:

"Human aging is like a book's chapters. Each chapter, or decade, brings changes. Babies grow into kids, teens become adults, and adults turn into seniors. Hair grays, skin wrinkles, and bones weaken. But aging isn't just physical. Brains slow, memories fade, and bodies need more rest. Some people age faster than others, like a book read quickly. But everyone ages, one chapter at a time."

"Human aging is when our bodies change over time. We grow taller as kids, then our bones get bigger, but not taller, as adults. Our muscles get weaker, and our skin gets wrinkled. We might not hear or see as well. Inside, our organs get older too. Our hearts may not pump as strongly, and our brains might not work as fast. This happens to everyone, but it happens faster for some people than others."
